name: Glass Cleaner
description: Ammonia (NH₃) is a powerful cleaning agent that effectively cuts through grease and grime on glass surfaces. It works through a process called **saponification**, where it reacts with fatty acids in grease to form soap, which is then easily rinsed away with water. A simplified equation for this reaction with a fat (triglyceride) is: Fat + 3NH₃ → Glycerol + 3 Ammonium Soap.
funFact: The distinctive sharp smell of ammonia is actually a warning property; it's so irritating to the human nose that we can detect it at concentrations as low as 5 parts per million.

name: Soap
description: Soap is a surfactant, a substance that reduces the surface tension of water, allowing it to mix with oils and dirt so they can be washed away. It is produced via a chemical reaction called **saponification**, where a fat or oil (a triglyceride) reacts with a strong base like sodium hydroxide (NaOH). The general equation is: Triglyceride + 3NaOH → Glycerol + 3 Soap (Fatty acid salts).
funFact: The first documented evidence of soap-like materials dates back to ancient Babylon around 2800 BC, where it was likely used for cleaning wool.

name: Detergent
description: Unlike soap, detergents are synthetic surfactants that work well even in hard water. They clean by reducing water's surface tension and emulsifying oils. Many modern detergents are derived from petroleum and contain enzymes to break down protein-based stains. A key reaction in their function is the sequestration of calcium and magnesium ions (which cause hardness) by compounds like phosphates or zeolites, preventing them from interfering with the cleaning process.
funFact: The first synthetic detergent, Nekal, was developed in Germany during World War I due to a shortage of fats and oils needed for soap production.

name: Shower Curtain
description: A shower curtain is typically made from polyethene (polyethylene), a polymer created through the **addition polymerization** of ethene monomers. Under high pressure and temperature with an initiator, the double bonds in ethene open up to form long chains. The reaction is: n CH₂=CH₂ → [−CH₂−CH₂−]ₙ. This process creates a lightweight, flexible, and waterproof material ideal for shower curtains.
funFact: Polyethylene was first industrially synthesized by accident in 1933 by chemists at Imperial Chemical Industries (ICI) who were experimenting with high pressures. The first batch looked like a waxy solid.

name: Toothbrush
description: The bristles of a toothbrush are commonly made from nylon, a synthetic polymer. Nylon is a polyamide formed via **condensation polymerization**. A common type, Nylon 6,6, is made by reacting hexamethylenediamine with adipic acid. In this reaction, each bond formation releases a small molecule, water. The general equation is: n H₂N-(CH₂)₆-NH₂ + n HOOC-(CH₂)₄-COOH → [−NH-(CH₂)₆-NH-CO-(CH₂)₄-CO−]ₙ + 2n H₂O.
funFact: The first nylon toothbrush, called "Doctor West's Miracle-Tuft", was introduced in 1938, replacing the more common animal-hair bristles.

name: Drain Cleaner
description: Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), also known as lye or caustic soda, is the active ingredient in many drain cleaners. It works by generating heat and converting the fats and grease that clog drains into soap through **saponification**. This reaction with a fat (glyceryl trioleate) is: (C₁₇H₃₃COO)₃C₃H₅ + 3NaOH → C₃H₅(OH)₃ + 3C₁₇H₃₃COONa. The soap produced is water-soluble, helping to dissolve the clog.
funFact: Sodium hydroxide is so caustic that it can dissolve organic materials like hair and flesh, which is why it's so effective on clogs but must be handled with extreme care.

name: Saline Spray
description: Saline spray is a simple solution of sodium chloride (NaCl) in water, made to be isotonic with bodily fluids. It is used to moisturize nasal passages and rinse away allergens or debris. The key property is the dissolution of the ionic compound in water, a process where the polar water molecules surround and separate the Na⁺ and Cl⁻ ions from the crystal lattice, a process that can be represented as: NaCl(s) + H₂O → Na⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq).
funFact: The concentration of saline solution (0.9% NaCl) is the same as the salt concentration in human blood.

name: Antiseptic
description: Iodine (I₂) is a powerful antiseptic used to disinfect minor cuts and scrapes. It works by oxidizing essential proteins and enzymes in microbial cells, leading to their death. When applied to the skin, it can react with itself and other compounds. In aqueous solution, it establishes an equilibrium with hypoiodous acid, which is also an effective antimicrobial agent: I₂ + H₂O ⇌ HOI + I⁻ + H⁺.
funFact: Iodine is a trace element essential for human health, as it is a key component of thyroid hormones. Before modern antiseptics, iodine was one of the most effective and widely used agents in surgery.

name: Heat Pack
description: A disposable heat pack relies on the exothermic **oxidation** of iron. When the pack is squeezed, an internal water bag breaks, allowing water and oxygen from the air to react with the iron powder inside. The chemical equation for this **rusting** process is: 4Fe(s) + 3O₂(g) + 2H₂O(l) → 2Fe₂O₃·H₂O(s) (hydrated iron(III) oxide). This reaction releases energy in the form of heat, warming the pack for several hours.
funFact: The heat pack will continue to generate heat until all the iron has been oxidized, after which it becomes a hard, rusty brick.

name: Toilet Cleaner
description: Hydrochloric acid (HCl) is a strong acid used in toilet bowl cleaners to dissolve mineral deposits, particularly limescale (calcium carbonate, CaCO₃). It works through an **acid-base** (neutralization) reaction. The HCl reacts with the insoluble limescale, converting it into soluble calcium chloride, water, and carbon dioxide. The reaction is: 2HCl(aq) + CaCO₃(s) → CaCl₂(aq) + H₂O(l) + CO₂(g). The fizzing observed is the carbon dioxide gas being released.
funFact: Our own stomachs produce hydrochloric acid to help digest food. The concentration in the stomach (about 0.5%) is much lower than in some toilet cleaners, but it's still a potent acid.

name: Corrosion
description: Corrosion on iron or steel fixtures, commonly known as rust, is the result of an electrochemical process involving **oxidation**. In the presence of water and oxygen, iron atoms lose electrons (are oxidized) to form iron ions. These ions then react with water and oxygen to form hydrated iron(III) oxide, the reddish-brown rust we see. The simplified overall equation is: 4Fe(s) + 3O₂(g) + 2H₂O(l) → 2Fe₂O₃·H₂O(s). This process weakens the metal and causes it to flake away.
funFact: Rusting requires both oxygen and water. A car in a dry desert will rust very slowly, while one in a humid, coastal city will rust quickly.

name: Hand Sanitizer
description: Hand sanitizer typically contains a high concentration of ethanol (C₂H₅OH), which acts as an antiseptic by denaturing the proteins of microorganisms, effectively killing them. It does not involve a chemical reaction with the germs, but rather a physical disruption of their structure. Ethanol's effectiveness is concentration-dependent; it needs to be above 60% to be reliably effective, as water helps the alcohol penetrate the cell wall.
funFact: The ethanol in hand sanitizer is usually denatured, meaning a small amount of a bitter or foul-smelling substance is added to prevent people from drinking it.

name: Faucet
description: A shiny, chrome-plated faucet is coated with a thin layer of chromium (Cr). This is done through **electroplating**, an electrolytic process where the faucet (the cathode) is placed in a solution of chromium ions. When an electric current is passed, chromium ions are reduced and deposited as a solid metal onto the faucet's surface. The cathodic reaction is: Cr³⁺(aq) + 3e⁻ → Cr(s). This layer provides a decorative, corrosion-resistant, and hard-wearing surface.
funFact: The element chromium gets its name from the Greek word "chroma," meaning color, because many of its compounds are intensely and beautifully colored.

name: Cold Pack
description: An instant cold pack works by triggering an **endothermic** reaction. The pack contains water and a separate compartment with a salt, often ammonium nitrate (NH₄NO₃) or urea. When the pack is squeezed, the inner compartment breaks, and the salt dissolves in the water. This dissolution process absorbs a large amount of heat energy from its surroundings, causing the pack to become cold rapidly. The process for ammonium nitrate is: NH₄NO₃(s) + H₂O → NH₄⁺(aq) + NO₃⁻(aq) (ΔH > 0).
funFact: Some modern cold packs use urea as the salt, which is less hazardous than ammonium nitrate but still produces a significant cooling effect.

name: Limescale
description: Limescale is the hard, chalky deposit primarily composed of calcium carbonate (CaCO₃). It forms when hard water, which contains dissolved calcium ions (Ca²⁺), is heated or evaporates. The heating process can reverse the reaction that initially dissolved the carbonate, causing solid calcium carbonate to precipitate out of the solution: Ca²⁺(aq) + 2HCO₃⁻(aq) → CaCO₃(s) + CO₂(g) + H₂O(l). This is why limescale is commonly found in kettles, pipes, and toilet bowls.
funFact: The word "limescale" comes from "lime," an old term for calcium oxide, which is derived from heating limestone (calcium carbonate).

name: Hand Sanitizer
description: This is a duplicate of `c2h5oh_handSanitizer__toilet`. Hand sanitizer uses ethanol (C₂H₅OH) to kill germs by **denaturing their proteins**. For it to be effective, it needs to be at the correct concentration (typically 60-80% ethanol in water). The water in the solution plays a crucial role by slowing down the evaporation of the alcohol, allowing it more time to disrupt the microorganism's cell membrane and coagulate its essential proteins.
funFact: While "alcohol-free" sanitizers exist, often using benzalkonium chloride, studies have shown that alcohol-based ones (with ethanol or isopropanol) are generally more rapidly effective against a broader spectrum of germs.

name: Galvanized Trash Can
description: A galvanized trash can is made of steel coated with a layer of zinc (Zn) through a process called galvanization. This protects the underlying iron from rusting through **cathodic protection**, or **sacrificial protection**. Zinc is more reactive than iron, so it will oxidize in preference to the iron. If the coating is scratched, the zinc acts as the anode in an electrochemical cell, corroding instead of the iron. The anodic reaction is: Zn(s) → Zn²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻.
funFact: The name "galvanizing" comes from the Italian scientist Luigi Galvani, whose experiments with frogs' legs in the late 1700s led to the discovery of the electrochemical principles behind the process.

name: Water Pitcher
description: A water pitcher holds water (H₂O), the universal solvent. Its unique chemical properties, such as high specific heat capacity and its ability to form hydrogen bonds, make it essential for life. A key equilibrium in water is its autoionization, where two water molecules react to form hydronium and hydroxide ions: 2H₂O(l) ⇌ H₃O⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq). This equilibrium is central to the concept of pH.
funFact: Water is one of the few substances that is less dense as a solid (ice) than as a liquid, which is why ice floats in your pitcher of water.

name: Spoon
description: A spoon made of iron (Fe), or more commonly steel (an alloy of iron with carbon and other elements), is used for eating and serving food. While iron is strong, it is prone to **oxidation** (rusting) in the presence of moisture and oxygen. The overall reaction for rust formation is: 4Fe(s) + 3O₂(g) + 2H₂O(l) → 2Fe₂O₃·H₂O(s). To prevent this, iron spoons are often coated with another material like chromium (stainless steel) or a protective layer of tin or enamel.
funFact: Iron is the most abundant element by mass on Earth, making up a large part of the planet's core.

name: Spoon
description: This spoon is likely made of stainless steel, which contains chromium (Cr). The chromium is what makes it "stainless." It forms a thin, transparent, and self-healing layer of chromium(III) oxide (Cr₂O₃) on the surface through a process called **passivation**. This layer is inert and prevents the iron in the steel from coming into contact with oxygen and water, thus preventing rust. The formation reaction is: 4Cr(s) + 3O₂(g) → 2Cr₂O₃(s).
funFact: Chromium is what gives rubies their red color. The gemstone corundum (aluminum oxide) is normally colorless, but when a tiny amount of chromium replaces some aluminum atoms, the crystal becomes deep red.

name: Food Container
description: Polypropylene (PP) is a common thermoplastic polymer used for food containers because of its high melting point, chemical resistance, and durability. It is produced via **chain-growth polymerization** from the propylene monomer. The reaction is an addition polymerization similar to polyethylene: n CH₂=CH–CH₃ → [−CH₂−CH(CH₃)−]ₙ. This structure gives it the flexibility and strength needed for reusable food storage.
funFact: Polypropylene has a "memory," meaning it can be bent repeatedly without breaking. This is why it's used for living hinges, like the ones on a bottle cap.

name: Food Containers
description: These food containers are made from polyethylene (PE), a flexible and inexpensive plastic. It's formed through the **addition polymerization** of ethene. There are different types, like high-density polyethylene (HDPE) for stiffer containers and low-density polyethylene (LDPE) for more flexible ones. The fundamental reaction is: n CH₂=CH₂ → [−CH₂−CH₂−]ₙ. This process creates long, inert hydrocarbon chains that are safe for food contact.
funFact: Recycling symbol #2 (HDPE) and #4 (LDPE) both refer to different densities of polyethylene.

name: Cooking Gas
description: Methane (CH₄) is the primary component of natural gas, used for cooking on gas stoves. When ignited, it undergoes a **combustion** reaction with oxygen from the air. This is a highly exothermic **redox** reaction, producing heat, carbon dioxide, and water vapor. The balanced equation is: CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(g) (ΔH = -890 kJ/mol). The blue flame seen on a gas stove indicates complete combustion with sufficient oxygen.
funFact: Before natural gas was widely available, town gas was used. It was a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide, produced from coal, and was highly toxic due to the carbon monoxide content.

name: Cooking Gas
description: This refers to cooking gas that is pure hydrogen (H₂). While not common today, hydrogen is a clean fuel that undergoes **combustion** with oxygen to produce only water vapor as a byproduct. The highly exothermic reaction is: 2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(g) (ΔH = -286 kJ/mol per mole of H₂). Its use is being explored as a sustainable energy source.
funFact: The Hindenburg disaster, often associated with hydrogen's danger, was actually the outer fabric coating (which was similar to rocket fuel) that burned, not the hydrogen itself, which burned invisibly above the airship.

name: Table Salt
description: Table salt is primarily sodium chloride (NaCl), an ionic compound essential for human life and a fundamental seasoning. Its production often involves the evaporation of brine, reversing the dissolution process: Na⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq) → NaCl(s). Table salt often contains additives like iodine (as potassium iodide) to prevent iodine deficiency, and anti-caking agents to keep it free-flowing.
funFact: The word "salary" comes from the Latin word "salarium," which was an allowance paid to Roman soldiers to buy salt, a valuable and essential commodity.

name: Food Warmer
description: A self-heating food warmer uses the exothermic reaction of calcium oxide (CaO), or quicklime, with water. When the pack is activated, water comes into contact with the CaO, initiating a vigorous **hydration** reaction. This produces calcium hydroxide and a significant amount of heat. The reaction is: CaO(s) + H₂O(l) → Ca(OH)₂(aq) (ΔH = -65.2 kJ/mol). The heat generated is then transferred to the food.
funFact: This same reaction was historically used in "self-heating" cans of coffee or hot chocolate, though they were often unreliable.

name: Ice Cube
description: An ice cube is the solid, crystalline form of water (H₂O). It forms when liquid water is cooled below its freezing point (0°C or 32°F at standard pressure). This is a **phase change** (solidification), represented as: H₂O(l) → H₂O(s). During this process, the water molecules arrange themselves into a hexagonal crystal lattice, which is less dense than liquid water, causing the ice to expand and float.
funFact: The expansion of water upon freezing is why ice cubes float in your drink and why water pipes can burst in winter.

name: Cast Iron Pan
description: A cast iron pan is made from an alloy of iron (Fe) and carbon. It is prized for its excellent heat retention and durability. However, it is highly susceptible to **oxidation** (rusting) if not properly maintained. The rusting process is: 4Fe(s) + 3O₂(g) + 2H₂O(l) → 2Fe₂O₃·H₂O(s). To prevent this, cast iron pans are "seasoned" by baking a thin layer of oil onto the surface, which polymerizes to form a protective, non-stick coating.
funFact: Cast iron pans can last for generations if cared for properly. Some of the oldest pans in existence are over a century old and still in daily use.

name: Vinegar
description: Vinegar is a dilute solution of acetic acid (CH₃COOH) in water, typically around 4-8%. It is produced by a two-step fermentation process. First, sugars are converted to ethanol by yeast (fermentation). Then, acetic acid bacteria (Acetobacter) carry out an **oxidation** reaction, converting the ethanol to acetic acid: C₂H₅OH(aq) + O₂(g) → CH₃COOH(aq) + H₂O(l). This process is why wine or cider left exposed to air will eventually turn sour and become vinegar.
funFact: The word "vinegar" comes from the Old French "vin aigre," meaning "sour wine."

name: Beer
description: Beer is an alcoholic beverage where ethanol (C₂H₅OH) is produced by yeast during fermentation. The yeast metabolizes sugars (like maltose from barley) in the absence of oxygen. This is an anaerobic process where the sugars are converted into ethanol and carbon dioxide. The simplified overall equation for glucose fermentation is: C₆H₁₂O₆(aq) → 2C₂H₅OH(aq) + 2CO₂(g). This reaction is also known as **alcoholic fermentation**.
funFact: The bubbles in beer are carbon dioxide (CO₂) produced during fermentation. In some beers, additional CO₂ is added later for extra fizz.

name: Carton
description: An egg carton holds a dozen eggs, which is a perfect analogy for the mole in chemistry—often called "the chemist's dozen." Just as a dozen represents 12 of something, a mole represents 6.022 × 10²³ particles (Avogadro's number) of a substance. This enormous number allows chemists to count atoms and molecules by weighing them. For example, one mole of carbon atoms has a mass of 12 grams. While the eggs themselves are a complex biological system containing proteins and fats, the carton serves as a tangible representation of this fundamental counting unit in chemistry.
funFact: The name "mole" was popularized by the Nobel Prize-winning chemist Wilhelm Ostwald, who derived it from the Latin word "moles," meaning a large mass or heap—fitting for a number so vast it would take the entire population of Earth counting 24/7 over a million years to reach it!

name: Cookware
description: Copper (Cu) cookware is prized by chefs for its excellent and even heat conductivity. However, copper can react with acidic foods, leading to the formation of toxic copper salts. For this reason, copper cookware is almost always lined with a non-reactive metal like tin or stainless steel. The unwanted reaction with an acid (like in tomatoes) can be represented as: Cu(s) + 2H⁺(aq) → Cu²⁺(aq) + H₂(g). The copper ions (Cu²⁺) are what can be toxic and also cause a metallic taste.
funFact: The Statue of Liberty is made of copper and has turned green due to the formation of a protective layer of verdigris, a mixture of copper carbonates, sulfates, and hydroxides.

name: Soda
description: The "fizz" in soda comes from dissolved carbon dioxide (CO₂) gas. This is a physical process called **carbonation**, where CO₂ is forced into the liquid under pressure. In the water, some of the CO₂ reacts to form carbonic acid, which gives soda its slight tang. The equilibrium is: CO₂(g) + H₂O(l) ⇌ H₂CO₃(aq). When you open the bottle, you release the pressure, shifting the equilibrium to the left, and the CO₂ comes out of solution as bubbles.
funFact: The world's first marketed soft drink was "soft" because it didn't contain alcohol. It was carbonated water, sold in the late 18th century as a therapeutic beverage.

name: Antacid Tablet
description: These tablets contain magnesium hydroxide (Mg(OH)₂), a common antacid used to relieve heartburn and indigestion. It works by neutralizing excess stomach acid (hydrochloric acid, HCl) through an **acid-base** reaction. This is a neutralization reaction, producing a salt (magnesium chloride) and water. The equation is: Mg(OH)₂(s) + 2HCl(aq) → MgCl₂(aq) + 2H₂O(l).
funFact: Magnesium hydroxide is also known as "milk of magnesia" when suspended in water. It's also a mild laxative, which is why some antacids combine it with aluminum hydroxide, which has the opposite effect.

name: Antacid Tablet
description: These tablets contain aluminum hydroxide (Al(OH)₃). It is used as an antacid to neutralize stomach acid. It works via a similar **neutralization** reaction, reacting with hydrochloric acid (HCl) to form aluminum chloride and water. The balanced equation is: Al(OH)₃(s) + 3HCl(aq) → AlCl₃(aq) + 3H₂O(l). It is often combined with magnesium hydroxide to balance the constipating effect of aluminum with the laxative effect of magnesium.
funFact: The aluminum in these tablets is not significantly absorbed by the body, but it can bind to phosphate in the gut, which is why they are sometimes used to treat high phosphate levels in kidney disease.

name: Aluminium Foil
description: Aluminum foil is a thin sheet of aluminum (Al) metal, prized for its malleability and resistance to corrosion. Its corrosion resistance comes from **passivation**; it instantly forms a thin, transparent layer of aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃) on its surface when exposed to air. This reaction is: 4Al(s) + 3O₂(g) → 2Al₂O₃(s). This oxide layer is tough and impermeable, protecting the underlying metal from further reaction.
funFact: Aluminum was once more valuable than gold. In the mid-19th century, it was considered a precious metal, and the cap of the Washington Monument was made from it to showcase its value.

name: Baking Soda
description: Baking soda (sodium bicarbonate, NaHCO₃) is a leavening agent in baking. When mixed with an acid (like vinegar, buttermilk, or cream of tartar) and moisture, it undergoes an **acid-base** reaction, producing carbon dioxide gas. The CO₂ bubbles get trapped in the batter, causing it to rise. A typical reaction with an acid (HA) is: NaHCO₃(s) + HA(aq) → NaA(aq) + H₂O(l) + CO₂(g). It can also decompose when heated alone: 2NaHCO₃(s) → Na₂CO₃(s) + H₂O(g) + CO₂(g).
funFact: Baking soda is also a fantastic deodorizer because it reacts with and neutralizes odor-causing acids and bases in the air and on surfaces.

name: Can
description: An aluminum can is a container for beverages made primarily from aluminum (Al). Like aluminum foil, its resistance to corrosion from the drink inside is due to a thin, protective layer of aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃) formed through **passivation**: 4Al(s) + 3O₂(g) → 2Al₂O₃(s). The inside of the can is also often coated with a polymer to prevent any metallic taste or reaction with acidic drinks.
funFact: Recycling a single aluminum can saves enough energy to run a television for about three hours. Aluminum is infinitely recyclable without loss of quality.

name: Methylated Spirits
description: Methylated spirits, also known as denatured alcohol, is ethanol (C₂H₅OH) that has been rendered undrinkable by the addition of poisonous or foul-tasting chemicals like methanol or pyridine. It is used as a solvent and fuel for spirit burners. As a solvent, it relies on the principle of "like dissolves like," effectively dissolving non-polar compounds like oils, resins, and some paints.
funFact: The bitter, foul taste in some modern methylated spirits comes from a compound called denatonium, which is recognized as the most bitter chemical compound known.

name: Candle
description: A candle is typically made of paraffin wax (a hydrocarbon). When it burns, it undergoes **combustion**. Incomplete combustion, often due to a lack of oxygen, produces soot. Soot is primarily composed of amorphous carbon. The incomplete combustion of a simple hydrocarbon like methane (CH₄) can be represented as: CH₄(g) + O₂(g) → C(s) + 2H₂O(g). The solid carbon particles are what we see as black smoke.
funFact: A candle flame is a self-sustaining process. The heat of the flame melts the wax, which is drawn up the wick by capillary action, where it vaporizes and burns.

name: Soap Powder
description: Soap powder, or laundry detergent, works through the principle of **emulsification**. Its molecules have a hydrophilic (water-loving) head and a hydrophobic (water-fearing) tail. The hydrophobic tails attach to grease and dirt, while the hydrophilic heads face the water. This forms structures called micelles, which suspend the dirt in the water so it can be rinsed away. This action doesn't involve a chemical change to the dirt, but a physical one.
funFact: The first mass-produced laundry detergent, "Persil," was introduced in Germany in 1907. Its name comes from two of its main ingredients: **Per**borate and **Sil**icate.

name: Container
description: This is another polypropylene (PP) container, formed through **addition polymerization** of propylene monomers: n CH₂=CH–CH₃ → [−CH₂−CH(CH₃)−]ₙ. Its high chemical resistance and ability to withstand heat make it ideal for storing a variety of kitchen items, from dry goods to leftovers.
funFact: Polypropylene is also used in many medical applications, including syringes and suture materials, because of its resistance to bacteria and chemicals.

name: Juice Cup
description: This cup demonstrates a beautiful chemical equilibrium using two common fruit juices. Blueberry juice contains anthocyanins—natural pigments that change color based on the acidity (pH) of their environment. When lemon juice (containing citric acid, C₆H₈O₇) is added to the blueberry juice, the solution becomes more acidic, shifting the anthocyanin equilibrium toward its red/pink form. This reversible reaction can be represented as: Anthocyanin (blue, basic form) + H⁺ ⇌ Anthocyanin (red, acidic form). As you continue to add lemon juice, the color transitions from blue to purple to pink, creating a visible pH indicator effect right in the cup!
funFact: The food industry uses this effect in "mood drinks" and color-changing cocktails, and as natural pH indicators in smart packaging to detect spoilage—all without synthetic dyes!

name: Color-Changing Mug
description: A color-changing mug contains a special pigment, often a **leuco dye**, embedded in the plastic or glaze. The color change is triggered by heat (thermochromism). The dye exists in two forms: a colored, closed-ring structure (lactone form) and a colorless, open-ring structure. A reversible chemical equilibrium between these two forms is established. Heat shifts the equilibrium, causing the ring to open or close and the color to appear or disappear. This can be represented as: Dye (closed, colored) ⇌ Dye (open, colorless) (ΔH).
funFact: Some thermochromic pigments are also used in mood rings, which supposedly change color with your body temperature, and in battery test strips.

name: Soap
description: Same as `soap_soap__toilet`. Soap cleans through the formation of micelles, which encapsulate dirt and grease. This is a physical process driven by the amphiphilic nature of soap molecules. The fundamental chemical reaction to make it is **saponification**: Fat + 3NaOH → Glycerol + 3 Soap.
funFact: While we think of soap for cleaning, it can also be used as a lubricant and as a simple insecticide in gardening.

name: Seafoam
description: Seafoam is created when wind and waves churn air into seawater. It is stabilized by organic matter dissolved in the water, such as proteins, lipids, and algae. These molecules act as surfactants, similar to soap, and their hydrophobic and hydrophilic parts help form stable bubbles. The water itself undergoes constant **autoionization**: 2H₂O(l) ⇌ H₃O⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq), but the foam is a physical, not a chemical, phenomenon.
funFact: Large seafoam events, while usually harmless, can sometimes be whipped up by storms and, in rare cases, can contain harmful algal blooms or pollutants.

name: Balloons
description: Helium (He) is a noble gas that is less dense than air, which is why helium balloons float. Its chemical inertness, due to its full valence electron shell, makes it safe and non-flammable for this use. It is obtained as a byproduct of natural gas extraction and does not undergo any chemical reactions in this application.
funFact: Helium is the only element in the universe that was not formed through nuclear fusion in stars; it was mostly created during the Big Bang.

name: Sulphur Rock
description: This sulfur rock is composed of elemental sulfur, which at room temperature exists as cyclic crown-shaped molecules of eight sulfur atoms, S₈. It can be found near volcanic areas and hot springs. Sulfur can undergo **combustion** in air, burning with a blue flame to produce sulfur dioxide, a pungent and toxic gas. The reaction is: S₈(s) + 8O₂(g) → 8SO₂(g). This is a key step in the industrial production of sulfuric acid.
funFact: Sulfur has a distinct smell often associated with hell or rotten eggs. However, pure sulfur is actually odorless. The smell is from other sulfur compounds, like hydrogen sulfide.

name: Rock
description: This rock contains copper(II) oxide (CuO), a black mineral. It can form naturally from the weathering of copper-bearing rocks. CuO can be reduced to metallic copper by heating it with a reducing agent like carbon (coke) in a process called **smelting**. The simplified **redox** reaction is: 2CuO(s) + C(s) → 2Cu(s) + CO₂(g). This is one of the fundamental reactions in the extraction of copper from its ores.
funFact: Copper(II) oxide is used as a pigment to produce blue, red, and green colors in ceramics, glass, and artificial gemstones.

name: Tide Pool
description: A tide pool is a small pocket of seawater left behind by the receding tide. This water is a complex saline solution, with sodium chloride (NaCl) being the most abundant salt. As the sun evaporates the water in the pool, the concentration of NaCl increases. This can be thought of as the reverse of dissolution: Na⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq) → NaCl(s), leading to the formation of salt crystals around the edges of the pool.
funFact: The salinity of the ocean is not uniform. In tide pools, especially in hot climates, the water can become significantly saltier than the open ocean due to evaporation.

name: Sea Ice
description: Sea ice forms when the temperature of ocean water drops below its freezing point, which is about -1.8°C (28.8°F) due to the salt content. It is a **phase change** from liquid to solid: H₂O(l) → H₂O(s). Interestingly, when seawater freezes, most of the salt is expelled from the ice crystal structure, forming pockets of highly concentrated brine. This process makes the remaining ice much less salty than the original seawater.
funFact: Sea ice plays a crucial role in Earth's climate by reflecting sunlight back into space, a phenomenon known as the albedo effect.

name: Bubble
description: A bubble of argon (Ar) gas floating in the sky. Argon is a noble gas, making up about 0.93% of the Earth's atmosphere. It is chemically inert and does not form compounds under normal conditions, which is why it can exist as a simple, diatomic (monatomic) gas. Its lack of reactivity is due to its complete octet of valence electrons, fulfilling the **octet rule**.
funFact: Despite its inertness, an argon compound, argon fluorohydride (HArF), was created in a laboratory in 2000 at extremely cold temperatures (-265°C).

name: Sandcastle
description: A sandcastle is made from sand, which is primarily composed of small grains of silicon dioxide (SiO₂), also known as silica. The structure is held together by the surface tension of water, which forms "bridges" between the sand grains. The key to a good sandcastle is the right amount of water. When the water evaporates, the surface tension is lost, and the castle crumbles. This is a physical process, not a chemical one.
funFact: The best sand for sandcastles has a mix of grain sizes. Smaller grains fill the gaps between larger ones, creating a denser and more stable structure.

name: Bubble
description: The air at the beach is mostly nitrogen gas (N₂), making up about 78% of the atmosphere. Dinitrogen is a very stable molecule due to its strong triple bond (N≡N). This inertness means it doesn't readily participate in many chemical reactions. However, it can be "fixed" into more reactive compounds like ammonia (NH₃) through the **Haber-Bosch process**: N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) → 2NH₃(g).
funFact: The strong triple bond in nitrogen makes it so stable that it was a major challenge for chemists to find a way to "fix" it into a form usable by plants, a problem solved by the Haber-Bosch process which now feeds half the world.

name: Rock
description: This rock contains aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃), also known as alumina. In its pure, crystalline form, it is the mineral corundum. It is extremely hard and resistant to weathering. Alumina is the primary source of aluminum metal, which is extracted via the energy-intensive **Hall-Héroult process**. This is an electrolytic reduction: 2Al₂O₃(l) + 3C(s) → 4Al(l) + 3CO₂(g).
funFact: Rubies and sapphires are both gemstone varieties of corundum (Al₂O₃). The difference in color comes from trace impurities: chromium for red rubies, and iron and titanium for blue sapphires.

name: Atmosphere
description: The air we breathe contains about 21% oxygen (O₂), which is essential for cellular respiration in most life forms. Oxygen is a highly reactive gas that supports **combustion**. For example, when we burn a fuel like methane, it reacts with oxygen: CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(g). Oxygen's reactivity is also what drives the process of rusting and other oxidation reactions.
funFact: Almost all the oxygen in Earth's atmosphere was produced by cyanobacteria and later by plants through the process of photosynthesis.

name: Sailboat
description: The sails of a sailboat are often made from nylon or other synthetic fibers like Dacron (a type of polyester). Nylon is a polyamide, formed by **condensation polymerization**. The strength and flexibility of the polymer chains, held together by hydrogen bonds, make it an ideal material for withstanding strong winds. The reaction for Nylon 6,6 is: n H₂N-(CH₂)₆-NH₂ + n HOOC-(CH₂)₄-COOH → [−NH-(CH₂)₆-NH-CO-(CH₂)₄-CO−]ₙ + 2n H₂O.
funFact: Nylon was the first commercially successful synthetic polymer. It was famously used for women's stockings in the 1940s, which caused "nylon riots" as women clamored to buy them.

name: Sand
description: A sand cookie is a compacted lump of sand (SiO₂), similar to a sandcastle. It is formed when sand is moistened and then compressed. The cohesion is due to the surface tension of the water films between the sand grains. When the water evaporates, the structure loses its strength and crumbles. This is a classic example of a physical change, where the chemical identity of the SiO₂ remains unchanged.
funFact: Sand can also form permanent structures through a chemical change if it is heated to extreme temperatures, as in the making of glass or when lightning strikes sand, forming a fulgurite.

name: Glass
description: Glass found on the beach, often as smooth, frosted pieces called "sea glass," is primarily made of silicon dioxide (SiO₂). It is produced by melting silica (sand) with other additives at very high temperatures, and then cooling it rapidly so it doesn't form a crystalline structure. This creates an **amorphous solid** or a "supercooled liquid." Unlike the physical change of shaping a sandcastle, making glass involves a chemical and physical transformation.
funFact: Sea glass is formed from broken glass bottles and jars that have been tumbled and weathered by the ocean for many years, often decades.

name: Guardrail
description: A steel guardrail is often coated with zinc (Zn) to protect it from rust. This process, known as galvanization, uses the principle of **cathodic protection** (or sacrificial protection). Zinc is more easily oxidized than iron. If the coating is scratched, the zinc will corrode preferentially, acting as a sacrificial anode. The oxidation reaction is: Zn(s) → Zn²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻. The electrons released then protect the iron from oxidizing.
funFact: The zinc coating on a guardrail will slowly wear away over decades, sacrificing itself to protect the underlying steel. This is why galvanized structures last so long outdoors.

name: Exhaust
description: Car exhaust contains unburned hydrocarbons (CₓHᵧ), a result of incomplete combustion of fuel. This is a pollutant that contributes to smog formation. Ideally, fuel would undergo **complete combustion**: CₓHᵧ + (x + y/4)O₂ → xCO₂ + (y/2)H₂O. However, in an engine, there isn't always enough time or oxygen for this to happen fully, leading to the emission of the original fuel molecules.
funFact: Catalytic converters in cars are designed to complete the combustion of these unburned hydrocarbons, converting them into less harmful carbon dioxide and water vapor.

name: Exhaust
description: Soot in exhaust is a sign of **incomplete combustion**. It consists of fine particles of amorphous carbon (C) and is a major component of diesel particulate matter. The chemical equation for the incomplete combustion of a hydrocarbon, like octane (C₈H₁₈), can be represented as: 2C₈H₁₈(l) + 17O₂(g) → 16C(s) + 18H₂O(g). This black smoke is both an environmental pollutant and a health hazard.
funFact: Diesel engines produce significantly more soot than gasoline engines, which is why diesel vehicles are often equipped with diesel particulate filters (DPFs) to trap this material.

name: Exhaust
description: Suspended particulates, or particulate matter (PM), are tiny particles of solids or liquids suspended in the air. At a gas station, these can come from vehicle exhaust (soot), industrial emissions, or road dust. They are a complex mixture, not a single chemical, and contribute to air pollution and respiratory problems. They can act as surfaces for other chemical reactions, such as the oxidation of SO₂ to SO₃, which leads to acid rain.
funFact: PM2.5, which refers to particles smaller than 2.5 micrometers, is particularly dangerous because they can penetrate deep into the lungs and even enter the bloodstream.

name: Factory Emission
description: Sulfur dioxide (SO₂) is a gas produced primarily from the burning of fossil fuels (like coal and oil) that contain sulfur impurities. It is a major contributor to acid rain. In the atmosphere, SO₂ can be further oxidized to sulfur trioxide (SO₃), which then reacts with water to form sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄): 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2SO₃(g), followed by SO₃(g) + H₂O(l) → H₂SO₄(aq).
funFact: Sulfur dioxide is also responsible for the characteristic smell of struck matches, as the striking surface contains sulfur compounds.

name: Sandbag
description: A sandbag is a bag filled with sand (SiO₂). They are used for flood control, weight, and ballast. The sand itself is inert and provides mass. The sand's chemical stability is due to the strong silicon-oxygen bonds in its SiO₂ structure, making it highly resistant to weathering and chemical attack.
funFact: Sandbags are also used in military fortifications to absorb bullets and shrapnel. The sand's granular structure is very effective at dissipating kinetic energy.

name: Pipes
description: Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes are used for plumbing, drainage, and electrical conduit. PVC is produced by the **addition polymerization** of vinyl chloride monomer (CH₂=CHCl). The reaction is: n CH₂=CH–Cl → [−CH₂−CHCl−]ₙ. The presence of chlorine atoms in the polymer chain gives PVC its flame resistance and durability.
funFact: PVC is one of the most widely produced synthetic plastics in the world. It can be made either rigid (for pipes) or flexible (for cables and flooring) by adding plasticizers.

name: Oil Refinery
description: An oil refinery is an industrial complex where crude oil (petroleum) is separated and converted into useful products like gasoline, diesel, and jet fuel. The primary process is **fractional distillation**, a physical separation based on boiling points. However, refineries also use chemical processes like **cracking**, where large hydrocarbon molecules are broken down into smaller, more valuable ones. For example: C₁₆H₃₄ → C₈H₁₈ + C₈H₁₆.
funFact: The modern oil refinery is a marvel of chemical engineering, and its products are the basis for not just fuels, but also plastics, lubricants, asphalt, and thousands of other chemicals.

name: Pump Nozzle
description: The pump nozzle dispenses petrol (gasoline), a complex mixture of hydrocarbons. The key property that makes it useful as a fuel is its ability to undergo **combustion** in an engine. The octane rating of petrol is a measure of its resistance to auto-ignition (knocking). The complete combustion of a representative octane (C₈H₁₈) is: 2C₈H₁₈(l) + 25O₂(g) → 16CO₂(g) + 18H₂O(g).
funFact: The "check valve" at the end of a petrol nozzle is what automatically shuts off the pump when the tank is full. It works by a vacuum created when the gasoline covers a small hole near the tip.

name: Car Part
description: This car part, often a battery terminal or wheel weight, is made of lead (Pb). Lead is dense, malleable, and resistant to corrosion. Its corrosion resistance comes from the formation of a protective layer, often of lead sulfate or lead oxide, on its surface. For example, in air, it forms a thin layer of lead(II) oxide: 2Pb(s) + O₂(g) → 2PbO(s). This passivation layer protects the underlying metal.
funFact: Because of its high density, lead is used in radiation shielding (e.g., in X-ray rooms) and as a soundproofer. Its use in gasoline (as tetraethyllead) was phased out due to its extreme toxicity.

name: Exhaust
description: Nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) is a reddish-brown, toxic gas found in vehicle exhaust. It is formed when nitrogen and oxygen in the air react under the high temperature and pressure of an engine's combustion chamber. This is an endothermic reaction: N₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2NO(g). The nitric oxide (NO) then rapidly reacts with more oxygen in the air to form NO₂: 2NO(g) + O₂(g) → 2NO₂(g). NO₂ is a major component of smog and acid rain.
funFact: Nitrogen dioxide is responsible for the brownish haze often seen in smog over cities.

name: Exhaust
description: Nitric oxide (NO) is a colorless gas formed in high-temperature combustion processes, such as in a car engine. It is produced by the reaction of atmospheric nitrogen and oxygen: N₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2NO(g). While NO itself is a pollutant, it is also a crucial signaling molecule in the human body, involved in regulating blood pressure.
funFact: The discovery of nitric oxide's role as a biological signaling molecule was such a significant finding that it led to a Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1998.

name: Neon Sign
description: A classic "neon" sign contains neon gas (Ne) at low pressure. When a high voltage is applied across the gas, electrons are stripped from neon atoms. When these ions recombine with electrons, they release energy in the form of light. This is a process of **atomic emission**. The color of the light depends on the gas; pure neon emits a distinct red-orange glow.
funFact: Many "neon" signs are actually filled with other gases to get different colors. For example, argon with a drop of mercury gives a blue light, and helium produces a pale yellow or pinkish light.

name: Gas Flare
description: A gas flare is a combustion device used at oil refineries and wellheads to burn off flammable, waste, or excess gases, primarily methane (CH₄). This is a safety and environmental measure, converting potentially explosive gases into less dangerous compounds. The primary reaction is **combustion**: CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(g). In practice, flaring is often incomplete, producing soot and other pollutants.
funFact: Flaring is a significant source of global carbon dioxide emissions, and efforts are underway to capture this gas for use as a fuel rather than burning it off.

name: Engine Oil
description: Engine oil is a complex mixture of base oils (derived from petroleum) and various additives. Its primary function is to lubricate engine parts, reducing friction and wear. It can also undergo chemical changes during use, such as **oxidation** at high temperatures, which can lead to sludge formation. The base oil molecules (hydrocarbons) can react with oxygen: Hydrocarbon + O₂ → Oxidized products (alcohols, ketones, acids).
funFact: The "W" in oil grades like 10W-30 stands for "Winter," indicating the oil's viscosity at low temperatures.

name: Lead-Acid Accumulator
description: A lead-acid battery, commonly used in cars, works through a reversible **redox** reaction. It consists of lead dioxide (PbO₂) and sponge lead (Pb) electrodes in a sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) electrolyte. When the battery discharges, both electrodes convert to lead sulfate (PbSO₄). The overall reaction is: Pb(s) + PbO₂(s) + 2H₂SO₄(aq) ⇌ 2PbSO₄(s) + 2H₂O(l). When the battery is charged, this reaction is reversed.
funFact: A lead-acid battery is a "secondary cell," meaning it is rechargeable. All car batteries are of this type, and they can be recharged hundreds of times.

name: Fuel Can
description: A fuel can containing kerosene, a flammable hydrocarbon liquid. Kerosene is a fuel used for heating, lighting (in lamps), and in some types of jet engines (Jet-A fuel). It undergoes **combustion** to release energy. The complete combustion of a typical kerosene component, dodecane (C₁₂H₂₆), is: 2C₁₂H₂₆(l) + 37O₂(g) → 24CO₂(g) + 26H₂O(g).
funFact: Kerosene was first distilled from crude oil in the 1850s by a Canadian geologist named Abraham Gesner. It became known as "coal oil" because it was originally produced from coal.

name: Street Lamp
description: Mercury-vapor lamps produce light by passing an electric arc through vaporized mercury (Hg). The process involves exciting mercury atoms to higher energy levels. When they return to their ground state, they emit light, primarily in the ultraviolet (UV) range. This UV light then strikes a phosphor coating on the inside of the bulb, causing it to fluoresce and emit visible light. This is an example of **fluorescence**.
funFact: Mercury-vapor lamps were a major improvement over earlier street lighting, as they were more efficient and lasted longer than incandescent bulbs. They produce a characteristic blue-green light.

name: Lead-Acid Accumulator
description: Car battery acid is a solution of sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄), typically around 30-50% concentration. It serves as the electrolyte in a lead-acid battery. During discharge, the sulfuric acid is consumed, and its concentration decreases. It participates in the electrochemical reaction, providing sulfate ions to form lead sulfate on the electrodes. The key reaction involving the acid is: Pb(s) + HSO₄⁻(aq) → PbSO₄(s) + H⁺(aq) + 2e⁻.
funFact: Sulfuric acid is one of the most important industrial chemicals in the world. The amount of sulfuric acid produced by a country is often used as an indicator of its industrial strength.

name: Rust
description: Rust is the common name for the reddish-brown hydrated iron(III) oxide (Fe₂O₃·nH₂O) that forms on iron and steel. It is the result of an electrochemical **oxidation** process requiring oxygen, water, and an electrolyte (like salt). The overall chemical equation for rust formation is: 4Fe(s) + 3O₂(g) + 2H₂O(l) → 2Fe₂O₃·H₂O(s). Rust is not a protective layer; it flakes off, exposing fresh metal to further corrosion.
funFact: Rust expands, so it can cause iron and steel structures to crack and fail. This expansion is why old iron nails can leave rust stains and eventually crumble.

name: Steel Beam
description: A steel beam is an alloy primarily of iron (Fe) and carbon. It is the backbone of modern construction, prized for its high tensile strength. However, it is susceptible to corrosion. The corrosion (rusting) reaction is the same as for pure iron: 4Fe(s) + 3O₂(g) + 2H₂O(l) → 2Fe₂O₃·H₂O(s). To prevent this, steel beams are often painted or coated with a protective layer.
funFact: The carbon in steel makes it much harder and stronger than pure iron. By varying the amount of carbon and other alloying elements, a vast range of different steels with different properties can be created.

name: Pump Nozzle
description: This nozzle dispenses diesel fuel, a less volatile mixture of hydrocarbons than petrol. Diesel engines ignite the fuel by compression, not by a spark. The combustion of diesel is more complex but can be represented by the complete combustion of a representative hydrocarbon, like hexadecane (C₁₆H₃₄): 2C₁₆H₃₄(l) + 49O₂(g) → 32CO₂(g) + 34H₂O(g). Diesel fuel also contains sulfur, which contributes to SO₂ emissions.
funFact: Diesel fuel has a higher energy density than petrol, meaning it contains more energy per liter, which contributes to the better fuel economy of diesel engines.

name: Electrical Wire
description: Copper (Cu) wiring is used extensively in electrical applications due to its excellent electrical conductivity. It is relatively unreactive, but over time it can form a patina, a green layer of basic copper carbonate (Cu₂CO₃(OH)₂) when exposed to air and moisture. This reaction is: 2Cu(s) + H₂O(l) + CO₂(g) + O₂(g) → Cu₂CO₃(OH)₂(s). Unlike rust on iron, this patina protects the underlying copper from further corrosion.
funFact: Copper is the only metal other than gold that has a natural color other than gray or silver.

name: Coal
description: Coal is a combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock composed primarily of carbon, along with various other elements like hydrogen, sulfur, oxygen, and nitrogen. It is formed from plant matter that was buried and compressed over millions of years. When burned, it undergoes **combustion**: C(s) + O₂(g) → CO₂(g). This reaction releases a large amount of energy, which is used to generate electricity.
funFact: Coal is the most carbon-intensive fossil fuel, meaning it produces more CO₂ per unit of energy than oil or natural gas.

name: Exhaust
description: Carbon monoxide (CO) is a colorless, odorless, and highly toxic gas produced by the **incomplete combustion** of carbon-containing fuels. In a car engine, it forms when there is insufficient oxygen to fully oxidize the fuel carbon to CO₂. For example, for octane: 2C₈H₁₈(l) + 17O₂(g) → 16CO(g) + 18H₂O(g). Its toxicity comes from its ability to bind to hemoglobin in the blood, preventing the transport of oxygen.
funFact: Because CO is odorless and colorless, it is often called the "silent killer." Carbon monoxide detectors are essential safety devices in homes with fuel-burning appliances.

name: Catalytic Converter
description: A catalytic converter uses platinum (Pt) group metals (platinum, palladium, rhodium) as catalysts to reduce the toxicity of exhaust gases. It facilitates two main **redox** reactions: oxidation of CO to CO₂, and reduction of NOₓ to N₂. For example, the oxidation of carbon monoxide on the platinum surface is: 2CO(g) + O₂(g) → 2CO₂(g). The catalyst speeds up this reaction without being consumed itself.
funFact: Platinum is so effective as a catalyst because it can adsorb gases onto its surface, bringing them into close proximity and weakening their chemical bonds, making them more likely to react.

name: Mortar
description: Mortar is a workable paste used to bind building blocks like bricks and stones. A key component is slaked lime, calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)₂). It hardens by reacting with carbon dioxide (CO₂) from the air in a process called **carbonation**. This reaction reforms calcium carbonate (limestone), creating a durable structure: Ca(OH)₂(aq) + CO₂(g) → CaCO₃(s) + H₂O(l). This is the reverse of the reaction that produces quicklime.
funFact: This carbonation process takes a long time, and old mortar can continue to harden for centuries as it slowly absorbs CO₂ from the atmosphere.

name: Concrete Mix
description: Concrete mix contains cement, which is made from calcium oxide (CaO), or quicklime. When water is added to cement, a complex series of **hydration** reactions begins, forming a rigid, stone-like mass. The initial reaction of quicklime with water is: CaO(s) + H₂O(l) → Ca(OH)₂(aq) (ΔH = -65.2 kJ/mol). This is highly exothermic and produces calcium hydroxide, which then reacts with other components in the cement (like silicates and aluminates) to form the solid matrix.
funFact: The heat released when water is added to concrete mix is the same reaction used in self-heating food warmers, but on a much larger and more intense scale.

name: Limestone
description: Limestone, composed primarily of calcium carbonate (CaCO₃), is a fundamental building material and a key raw material for making cement. When heated strongly (calcined) in a kiln, it undergoes a **thermal decomposition** reaction to produce quicklime (calcium oxide, CaO) and carbon dioxide. This endothermic reaction is: CaCO₃(s) → CaO(s) + CO₂(g) (ΔH > 0). This is the first step in the cement-making process.
funFact: Limestone is often formed from the accumulated shells and skeletons of marine organisms, which are made of calcium carbonate.

name: Asphalt
description: Asphalt is a mixture of bitumen (a sticky, black, and highly viscous liquid or semi-solid form of petroleum) and aggregate (like sand and gravel). It is used for paving roads. Bitumen's properties arise from its complex mixture of large hydrocarbon molecules. Its ability to bind aggregate is a physical process, but its production from crude oil involves distillation and sometimes **air blowing**, where it is reacted with air to improve its properties.
funFact: The word "asphalt" comes from the Greek "asphaltos," meaning "secure" or "stable," referring to its use as a binder. Natural deposits of asphalt, like the La Brea Tar Pits, have trapped and preserved animals for thousands of years.

name: Patch
description: A bitumen patch is a smaller-scale application of asphalt or a similar bituminous material used for repairing roads or sealing cracks. The same principles apply as for asphalt: it's a mixture of heavy hydrocarbons from petroleum that acts as a waterproof and binding agent. It's applied hot or cold and hardens as it cools, a physical change, but the material can also age and become brittle due to **oxidation** from exposure to air and UV light.
funFact: Cold-patch asphalt, used for quick repairs, contains solvents that keep the bitumen liquid at ambient temperatures. When applied, the solvents evaporate, and the bitumen hardens.

name: Street Lamp
description: Some street lamps, particularly fluorescent or "neon" types, may contain argon (Ar) gas. When electricity is passed through the argon, it ionizes. Argon typically produces a faint blue or lavender glow. However, it is often used in combination with mercury vapor, where the argon helps to start the lamp. The mercury then produces UV light, which causes a phosphor coating to emit visible light.
funFact: Although it makes up nearly 1% of the air, argon was not discovered until 1894 by Lord Rayleigh and William Ramsay, who isolated it by removing all the other known gases from a sample of air.

name: Steel Cable
description: This steel cable is reinforced with aluminum (Al), or is perhaps an aluminum cable for power lines. Aluminum is lightweight, strong, and an excellent conductor of electricity. Its corrosion resistance comes from a thin, protective layer of aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃) formed through **passivation**: 4Al(s) + 3O₂(g) → 2Al₂O₃(s). This layer forms instantly and prevents further oxidation.
funFact: High-voltage power lines are often made of aluminum with a steel core for strength. Aluminum is preferred over copper for these long-distance lines because it is much lighter and cheaper, despite being a slightly poorer conductor.

name: Pipe
description: Copper (Cu) pipes are widely used in plumbing and for industrial applications due to their corrosion resistance and excellent thermal conductivity. Their durability is due to the formation of a protective patina, often a green layer of basic copper carbonate (Cu₂CO₃(OH)₂), which forms over time. The simplified formation reaction is: 2Cu(s) + O₂(g) + CO₂(g) + H₂O(l) → Cu₂CO₃(OH)₂(s).
funFact: Copper pipes have natural antimicrobial properties, which is one reason they are favored for plumbing in hospitals and for drinking water systems.

name: Zinc-Carbon Cell
description: A zinc-carbon battery is a common, inexpensive primary (non-rechargeable) battery. It uses a zinc can as the anode and a carbon rod surrounded by a paste of manganese dioxide (MnO₂) and ammonium chloride (NH₄Cl) as the cathode. The overall **redox** reaction is complex, but the anode reaction is the oxidation of zinc: Zn(s) → Zn²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻. These batteries are also known as "heavy duty" or "general purpose" batteries.
funFact: The zinc-carbon battery was the first commercial dry cell battery, developed by Carl Gassner in 1886. It was an improvement on the "wet" Leclanché cell.

name: Nickel-Metal Hydride Cell (NiMH)
description: A nickel-metal hydride (NiMH) battery is a type of rechargeable (secondary) battery. The anode is a hydrogen-absorbing alloy (often containing rare earth metals like lanthanum), and the cathode is nickel oxyhydroxide (NiOOH). During discharge, hydrogen is released from the anode alloy and reacts with the cathode. The overall reaction can be represented as: MH (metal hydride) + NiOOH → M + Ni(OH)₂. This reaction is reversed during charging.
funFact: NiMH batteries were a significant improvement over the older nickel-cadmium (NiCd) batteries because they have a higher capacity and are less toxic, as they do not contain the heavy metal cadmium.

name: Lithium Ion Cell
description: A lithium-ion (Li-ion) cell is a rechargeable battery where lithium ions move between the anode and cathode. During discharge, lithium ions are deintercalated from the anode (typically graphite) and intercalated into the cathode (a lithium metal oxide, like LiCoO₂). The anode reaction is: LiC₆ → C₆ + Li⁺ + e⁻. The cathode reaction is: Li₁₋ₓCoO₂ + xLi⁺ + xe⁻ → LiCoO₂. This movement of ions is reversible, allowing the battery to be recharged hundreds of times.
funFact: The 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to John B. Goodenough, M. Stanley Whittingham, and Akira Yoshino for their pioneering work in developing lithium-ion batteries.

name: Alkaline Manganese Cell
description: An alkaline battery is a primary (non-rechargeable) battery that gets its name from its alkaline electrolyte of potassium hydroxide (KOH). The anode is zinc powder, and the cathode is manganese dioxide (MnO₂). The overall **redox** reaction is: Zn(s) + 2MnO₂(s) ⇌ ZnO(s) + Mn₂O₃(s). The alkaline electrolyte allows for higher energy density and longer shelf life compared to older zinc-carbon batteries.
funFact: Alkaline batteries last much longer in high-drain devices (like digital cameras) than in low-drain devices (like clocks), due to the kinetics of the chemical reactions involved.

name: Fire Extinguisher
description: A CO₂ fire extinguisher contains pressurized carbon dioxide. It works by displacing oxygen around the fire and cooling the fuel. When discharged, the liquid CO₂ expands rapidly and turns into a gas in an endothermic process, forming "dry ice" snow. This is a physical change (CO₂(l) → CO₂(g)). CO₂ extinguishers are ideal for electrical fires and flammable liquid fires because they leave no residue.
funFact: CO₂ fire extinguishers are often identifiable by their lack of a pressure gauge. Instead, they are weighed periodically to ensure they haven't lost their contents.

name: Gas Cylinder
description: This gas cylinder contains argon (Ar), a noble gas used in labs as an inert atmosphere for air-sensitive reactions and for purging equipment. Its chemical inertness is due to its full valence electron shell, which means it does not readily form compounds. It provides an inert blanket to prevent unwanted **oxidation** reactions, such as: 2Mg(s) + O₂(g) → 2MgO(s). By replacing the air with argon, such reactions are prevented.
funFact: Argon is also used in welding as a shielding gas to protect the hot weld from reacting with oxygen and nitrogen in the air.

name: Magnesium Ribbon
description: This jar contains magnesium (Mg) ribbon, a highly reactive metal used in classic chemistry demonstrations. When ignited, it burns with an intensely bright white light in a vigorous **combustion** reaction with oxygen: 2Mg(s) + O₂(g) → 2MgO(s). This reaction is also a **redox** reaction, where magnesium is oxidized. The brilliant light was historically used in flash photography.
funFact: Magnesium ribbon can also burn in carbon dioxide, a property that makes it difficult to extinguish: 2Mg(s) + CO₂(g) → 2MgO(s) + C(s).

name: Gold Nugget
description: This jar contains gold (Au) nuggets or samples. Gold is a "noble metal," meaning it is highly resistant to corrosion and oxidation. Its lack of reactivity is why it is found in its native, metallic state in nature. It does not tarnish in air, and is resistant to most acids. It can, however, be dissolved in a mixture of nitric acid and hydrochloric acid (aqua regia) via a complex **redox** reaction: Au(s) + 4HCl(aq) + HNO₃(aq) → HAuCl₄(aq) + NO(g) + 2H₂O(l).
funFact: Gold is so malleable that a single gram can be hammered into a sheet of one square meter.

name: Platinum
description: This jar contains platinum (Pt), often in a finely divided form like platinum black or on a support, used as a catalyst. Platinum's ability to catalyze reactions, such as the **hydrogenation** of alkenes, comes from its ability to adsorb hydrogen and organic molecules onto its surface. For example, in the hydrogenation of ethene: C₂H₄(g) + H₂(g) → C₂H₆(g). The platinum surface weakens the bonds in H₂ and C₂H₄, allowing them to react.
funFact: Platinum is also a key component in the catalytic converters of cars, where it helps oxidize harmful CO and unburned hydrocarbons into CO₂ and water.

name: Silver Wire
description: This jar contains silver (Ag) wire. Silver is a relatively noble metal, but it tarnishes in air due to reaction with trace amounts of hydrogen sulfide (H₂S), forming a black layer of silver sulfide (Ag₂S). This **redox** reaction is: 4Ag(s) + 2H₂S(g) + O₂(g) → 2Ag₂S(s) + 2H₂O(l). This is why silver jewelry and utensils need regular polishing.
funFact: Silver has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of any metal.

name: Copper Wire
description: This jar contains copper (Cu) wire, a common material for demonstrating electrical conductivity and chemical reactions. Copper slowly tarnishes in air, forming a brown-black layer of copper(II) oxide: 2Cu(s) + O₂(g) → 2CuO(s). Over longer periods, especially in polluted air, it can form the characteristic green patina of basic copper carbonate.
funFact: Copper is an essential trace element for most living organisms, but in high concentrations, it is toxic.

name: Zinc Pellets
description: This jar contains zinc (Zn) pellets, which are often used in **single displacement** reactions. For example, when placed in a solution of copper(II) sulfate, the more reactive zinc will displace the less reactive copper: Zn(s) + CuSO₄(aq) → ZnSO₄(aq) + Cu(s). This is a classic **redox** reaction where zinc is oxidized (Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻) and copper is reduced (Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu).
funFact: Zinc is also used in galvanization (coating iron to prevent rust) because it is more reactive than iron and will corrode sacrificially.

name: Aluminium Roll
description: This jar contains aluminum (Al) in a rolled form. It is a reactive metal that is protected by a thin, tough layer of aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃) formed through **passivation**: 4Al(s) + 3O₂(g) → 2Al₂O₃(s). This layer is why aluminum doesn't appear to react with water or air under normal conditions, despite being quite reactive thermodynamically.
funFact: Aluminum can be used in the thermite reaction, where it reduces the oxide of another metal, typically iron(III) oxide, in a highly exothermic reaction: 2Al(s) + Fe₂O₃(s) → 2Fe(l) + Al₂O₃(s).

name: Calcium Rock
description: This jar contains calcium (Ca) in the form of small rocks or turnings. Calcium is an alkaline earth metal and is quite reactive. It will react readily with water, though less vigorously than its group neighbor, potassium. The reaction with water produces calcium hydroxide and hydrogen gas: Ca(s) + 2H₂O(l) → Ca(OH)₂(aq) + H₂(g). This is a **single displacement** and **redox** reaction.
funFact: Calcium is the fifth most abundant element in the Earth's crust and is essential for life, being a major component of bones and teeth as hydroxyapatite.

name: Firework (Lilac)
description: This is an icon or sample of potassium (K), a highly reactive alkali metal. It is so reactive that it must be stored under oil to prevent it from reacting with moisture in the air. Its reaction with water is famously vigorous, producing potassium hydroxide and hydrogen gas, which often ignites due to the heat of the reaction: 2K(s) + 2H₂O(l) → 2KOH(aq) + H₂(g) (ΔH strongly negative).
funFact: When potassium burns in air, it produces a mixture of potassium oxide, peroxide, and superoxide, which is why it's more dangerous to handle than sodium.

name: Gas Cylinder
description: This cylinder contains oxygen (O₂) gas, which is essential for **combustion** and respiration. In the lab, it is used to support combustion and in various oxidation reactions. For example, a glowing splint will relight in pure oxygen. The role of oxygen in combustion can be seen in the burning of magnesium: 2Mg(s) + O₂(g) → 2MgO(s).
funFact: Liquid oxygen, which is a pale blue color, is highly paramagnetic, meaning it is attracted to a magnetic field.

name: Preservative
description: Formalin is a solution of formaldehyde (HCHO) gas dissolved in water, typically around 37%. It is used as a fixative and preservative for biological specimens. It works by cross-linking proteins, a reaction that involves formaldehyde reacting with amine groups (-NH₂) in proteins to form a methylene bridge (-CH₂-). This process, known as **fixation**, essentially embalms the tissue. The reaction with a protein's amine group (R-NH₂) can be simplified as: R-NH₂ + HCHO + H₂N-R' → R-NH-CH₂-NH-R' + H₂O.
funFact: Formaldehyde is also a precursor to many other chemicals and materials, including the polymer Bakelite, one of the first synthetic plastics.

name: Iodine Jar
description: This jar contains iodine (I₂), which appears as dark purple, crystalline solid. It has a remarkable property called **sublimation**; when heated gently, it turns directly from a solid into a beautiful purple vapor without passing through a liquid phase: I₂(s) → I₂(g). It is used as a test for starch, forming a deep blue complex.
funFact: Iodine is the heaviest essential element used by life. A deficiency in iodine can cause goiter, an enlargement of the thyroid gland.

name: Bromine Jar
description: This jar contains bromine (Br₂), one of only two elements that is liquid at room temperature (the other being mercury). It is a fuming, reddish-brown, highly corrosive liquid with a strong, irritating odor. Its reactivity is shown in reactions with alkenes, such as in the test for unsaturation, where it adds across a double bond: C₂H₄(g) + Br₂(l) → C₂H₄Br₂(l) (1,2-dibromoethane). This **addition reaction** decolorizes the bromine.
funFact: The name "bromine" comes from the Greek word "bromos," meaning "stench," a fitting name for this foul-smelling element.

name: Potassium Permanganate Crystals
description: This jar contains potassium permanganate (KMnO₄) crystals, a powerful oxidizing agent. It is a deep purple color. In **redox** reactions, it is reduced, often to Mn²⁺ (colorless in dilute acid), and its color change can be used as an indicator. For example, in acidic conditions, it oxidizes oxalic acid (H₂C₂O₄): 2MnO₄⁻(aq) + 5H₂C₂O₄(aq) + 6H⁺(aq) → 2Mn²⁺(aq) + 10CO₂(g) + 8H₂O(l). The purple color disappears as the MnO₄⁻ is reduced.
funFact: Potassium permanganate is used in some water treatment plants to remove iron and manganese, and also to control taste and odor.

name: Potassium Dichromate Crystals
description: This jar contains potassium dichromate (K₂Cr₂O₇), a bright orange, crystalline solid and a strong oxidizing agent. Like KMnO₄, it is used in **redox** titrations. In acidic solution, it is reduced to the green Cr³⁺ ion. The half-reaction is: Cr₂O₇²⁻(aq) + 14H⁺(aq) + 6e⁻ → 2Cr³⁺(aq) + 7H₂O(l). It was also historically used in cleaning solutions for glassware.
funFact: Many chromium(VI) compounds, including dichromates, are known carcinogens and are highly toxic, requiring careful handling.

name: Sulphur
description: This jar contains sulfur (S₈), a yellow solid that exists as puckered rings of eight atoms. It is used in many lab experiments, including the synthesis of sulfuric acid. When heated, it melts to a blood-red liquid and can undergo polymerization. It burns with a blue flame to form sulfur dioxide: S₈(s) + 8O₂(g) → 8SO₂(g). This gas has a sharp, choking odor.
funFact: Sulfur is mentioned in the Bible and other ancient texts, where it was called "brimstone" (literally "burn-stone").

name: Yellow Phosphorus
description: This jar contains white phosphorus (P₄), a waxy, translucent solid that is extremely reactive and must be stored under water to prevent it from spontaneously igniting in air. It undergoes a rapid **combustion** reaction with oxygen: P₄(s) + 5O₂(g) → P₄O₁₀(s). This reaction produces a dense white smoke of phosphorus pentoxide. It also glows faintly in the dark due to a process called chemiluminescence, where it reacts with oxygen, releasing energy as light.
funFact: White phosphorus has been used in military applications for smoke screens and incendiary devices due to its spontaneous ignition in air.

name: Phenolphthalein
description: Phenolphthalein is a common acid-base indicator. It is colorless in acidic and neutral solutions, but turns pink or magenta in basic solutions. This color change is due to a structural change in the molecule (a change in its conjugation) when it loses protons in basic conditions. The equilibrium can be represented as: H₂In (colorless) ⇌ In²⁻ (pink) + 2H⁺.
funFact: Phenolphthalein was once used as a laxative, but its use was discontinued after studies suggested it might be a carcinogen.

name: Methyl Orange
description: Methyl orange is another common acid-base indicator. It changes color over a different pH range than phenolphthalein. It is red in acidic solutions and yellow in basic solutions. The color change is due to a structural change in the molecule (a change in its azo group) upon protonation/deprotonation. The equilibrium can be represented as: HIn (red) ⇌ In⁻ (yellow) + H⁺.
funFact: Unlike phenolphthalein, which has a sharp color change, methyl orange changes color over a wider pH range and through an intermediate orange color.

name: Mercury Jar
description: This jar contains mercury (Hg), a silvery, dense liquid metal at room temperature. It is used in some laboratory equipment like thermometers and barometers. It is relatively unreactive but can form alloys (amalgams) with many other metals. It will slowly tarnish in air, forming mercury(II) oxide: 2Hg(l) + O₂(g) → 2HgO(s). This reaction is slow at room temperature but faster when heated.
funFact: Mercury is highly toxic, especially as an organic compound like methylmercury, which can accumulate in the food chain and cause severe neurological damage.

name: Lead Roll
description: This is a sample of lead (Pb) in the form of a rolled sheet or strip. Lead is a dense, soft, malleable metal with a low melting point. It is relatively unreactive due to the formation of a protective layer, often of lead oxide or lead carbonate, on its surface. For example, in air it forms a thin layer of lead(II) oxide: 2Pb(s) + O₂(g) → 2PbO(s). This passivation layer gives it excellent corrosion resistance, making it useful for roofing, plumbing, and radiation shielding.
funFact: Lead was used by ancient Romans for plumbing, and the word "plumbing" actually comes from the Latin word for lead, plumbum (chemical symbol Pb). Ironically, this widespread use may have contributed to lead poisoning in the Roman elite due to their lead pipes and lead-sweetened wine!

name: Potassium Lump
description: This is a bottle containing potassium (K) metal, typically stored under oil. It is an alkali metal that is extremely reactive, especially with water. The reaction is highly exothermic and produces hydrogen gas, which often ignites: 2K(s) + 2H₂O(l) → 2KOH(aq) + H₂(g). This is a vigorous **single displacement** and **redox** reaction.
funFact: Potassium salts, like potassium chloride, are often used as a less-sodium salt substitute, though they can have a slightly bitter or metallic taste.

name: Methanol Bottle
description: This bottle contains methanol (CH₃OH), the simplest alcohol. It is a toxic, flammable liquid used as a solvent and fuel. Its combustion is similar to ethanol's: 2CH₃OH(l) + 3O₂(g) → 2CO₂(g) + 4H₂O(g). Its toxicity arises because the body metabolizes it to formaldehyde and formic acid, which can cause blindness and death.
funFact: Methanol is also known as wood alcohol because it was once produced primarily by the destructive distillation of wood.

name: Alkali Bottle
description: This bottle contains concentrated ammonia solution (NH₃(aq)), which is a strong base. Concentrated ammonia is often around 15-18 M and gives off pungent fumes. It participates in typical **acid-base** reactions, such as with hydrochloric acid to form ammonium chloride: NH₃(aq) + HCl(aq) → NH₄Cl(aq). The fumes of NH₃ and HCl can react in the air to form a white smoke of solid NH₄Cl.
funFact: Ammonia solutions can dissolve many metal ions by forming complex ions. For example, it dissolves copper(II) hydroxide to form the deep blue tetraamminecopper(II) complex: Cu(OH)₂(s) + 4NH₃(aq) → [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺(aq) + 2OH⁻(aq).

name: Alkali Bottle
description: This bottle contains dilute ammonia solution, a weaker base used for general laboratory work and as a cleaning agent. It reacts similarly to concentrated ammonia but with less vigor. It is used in testing for metal ions, as some metal hydroxides precipitate when NH₃ is added, and some of these precipitates dissolve in excess NH₃ due to complex formation.
funFact: The distinctive smell of ammonia is used in smelling salts to revive someone who has fainted, as it irritates the nasal membranes and triggers an inhalation reflex.

name: Acid Bottle
description: This bottle contains concentrated nitric acid (HNO₃), a strong acid and a powerful oxidizing agent. It is often fuming and corrosive. Its oxidizing power is shown by its reaction with copper metal, producing nitrogen dioxide (brown fumes) rather than hydrogen: Cu(s) + 4HNO₃(aq) → Cu(NO₃)₂(aq) + 2NO₂(g) + 2H₂O(l). This is a **redox** reaction where copper is oxidized and nitric acid is reduced.
funFact: A mixture of one part concentrated nitric acid and three parts concentrated hydrochloric acid is called "aqua regia" (royal water) because it can dissolve gold and platinum.

name: Acid Bottle
description: This bottle contains dilute sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄), a strong diprotic acid. It is used in many common acid reactions, such as with metals to produce hydrogen gas. For example, with zinc: Zn(s) + H₂SO₄(aq) → ZnSO₄(aq) + H₂(g). This is a classic **single displacement** reaction. It is also used in titrations.
funFact: Diluting concentrated sulfuric acid is highly exothermic and should always be done by adding acid to water, never water to acid, to prevent boiling and splashing.

name: Acid Bottle
description: This bottle contains dilute hydrochloric acid (HCl), a strong monoprotic acid used extensively in labs for acid-base reactions and for cleaning metals. It reacts with carbonates to produce carbon dioxide, a test for carbonate ions: 2HCl(aq) + Na₂CO₃(aq) → 2NaCl(aq) + H₂O(l) + CO₂(g).
funFact: Hydrochloric acid is also produced naturally in the stomach to aid in digestion.

name: Acid Bottle
description: This bottle contains concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl), which is typically around 12 M. It is a strong acid that fumes in moist air, forming a white mist of hydrochloric acid droplets. It is highly corrosive. Its fumes can react with ammonia fumes to form a white smoke of ammonium chloride: HCl(g) + NH₃(g) → NH₄Cl(s). This is often used as a test for the presence of either gas.
funFact: Concentrated hydrochloric acid is also known as "muriatic acid" and is used in the construction industry for cleaning masonry and etching concrete.

name: Acid Bottle
description: This bottle contains concentrated sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄), a dense, oily liquid that is a powerful dehydrating agent and strong acid. Its dehydrating property is shown by its reaction with sugar (sucrose, C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁), which removes water, leaving a column of black carbon: C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁(s) → 12C(s) + 11H₂O(l) (catalyzed by H₂SO₄). This is not a combustion, but a dehydration.
funFact: Because of its strong affinity for water, concentrated sulfuric acid is used as a drying agent in desiccators.

name: Nickel
description: This is a sample of nickel (Ni) used as a catalyst. Nickel is commonly used in **hydrogenation** reactions, such as converting unsaturated fats (with C=C bonds) into saturated fats (with C-C bonds). The reaction, for example with ethene, is: C₂H₄(g) + H₂(g) → C₂H₆(g). The nickel surface adsorbs both hydrogen and the alkene, weakening their bonds and bringing them together to react.
funFact: Finely divided nickel, known as Raney nickel, is an extremely efficient and widely used hydrogenation catalyst in both laboratories and industry.

name: Greenhouse Gas
description: This cylinder contains methane (CH₄) gas, the simplest hydrocarbon. It is used as a fuel and a reactant in the lab. It undergoes **combustion**: CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(g). It can also be used in substitution reactions with halogens under UV light.
funFact: Methane is a potent greenhouse gas, with a global warming potential many times higher than CO₂ over a 20-year period.

name: Catalyst
description: Manganese dioxide (MnO₂) is a common catalyst. A classic demonstration is its catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) into water and oxygen: 2H₂O₂(aq) → 2H₂O(l) + O₂(g). The MnO₂ provides a surface for the reaction, lowering the activation energy without being consumed in the process. This is why it is used in some commercial oxygen generators.
funFact: MnO₂ is also the black or dark brown material found in the center of zinc-carbon batteries, where it acts as a depolarizer.

name: NaOH Pellets
description: This bottle contains a sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution, a strong base. It is used in countless acid-base titrations and reactions.
